name: Fix ralph task ordering to respect priority and dependencies
notes: Root cause: ralph query tasks returns tasks in raw insertion order without: (1) sorting by priority (high>medium>low), (2) filtering out tasks with unmet deps. The task done command picks the first task from this list. Fix approach: In the tasks query endpoint, filter to only tasks whose deps are all in done list (or have no deps), then sort by priority descending. Also include priority field in response.
accept: ralph query tasks returns t-dot8 (high priority, no deps) as first task, not t-nvq1 (medium priority)

name: Fix ralph task done to respect task ID argument
notes: Root cause: The cmd_task function ignores the task ID argument (desc parameter) when action is done. It always marks pending[0] as done instead of finding the task matching the provided ID. Fix: In the if action == done block, add a check - if desc is provided, find the task by ID and error if not found. Only fall back to pending[0] when desc is None.
accept: ralph task done <task-id> marks the specified task, not the first pending one

name: Fix ralph task done to use task ID argument
notes: Root cause: In cmd_task() at line 5406-5412, the done action handler ignores the desc parameter (which receives the task ID from args.arg2) and always marks pending[0] as done instead of the specified task. Fix: Modify the done action handler to check if desc parameter is provided. If provided, find the task with matching ID and mark that one done. If not provided, keep current behavior.
accept: Running ralph task done <task-id> marks the specified task as done, not the first pending task

name: Fix ralph task done to use task ID argument
notes: In cmd_task() when action==done, the code always marks pending[0] (first pending task) as done. The desc parameter containing the task ID from ralph task done <task-id> is completely ignored. Fix: check if desc is provided and use next((t for t in pending if t.id == desc), None) to find the specific task by ID, with error handling if not found. If desc is not provided, keep current behavior of using pending[0].
accept: Running ralph task done <specific-task-id> marks that specific task as done, not the first pending task

name: Fix ralph task done to use task ID argument
notes: Root cause: In cmd_task() when action==done, the code always marks pending[0] as done, ignoring the desc parameter containing the task ID. Fix: Check if desc is provided; if so, use next((t for t in pending if t["id"] == desc), None) to find the specific task by ID with error handling if not found. If desc is not provided, keep current behavior of using pending[0].
accept: Running ralph task done <specific-task-id> marks that specific task as done, not the first pending task

name: Fix ralph task done to respect task ID argument
notes: Root cause: In cmd_task() around line 5405-5411, the done action ignores the desc parameter that would contain a task ID. It always uses pending[0]. Other actions like reject, delete, and accept correctly use desc as task ID when provided. Fix: when action==done and desc is provided, look up task by ID from pending tasks (follow accept action pattern on line 5479); if not found, error with list of pending task IDs; if desc is not provided, fall back to current behavior (pending[0]).
accept: ralph task done <task-id> marks the specified task as done, not the first pending task

name: Fix ralph task done to use task ID argument
notes: Root cause: In cmd_task() around line 5405, the done action ignores the optional task ID (desc parameter) and always marks pending[0]. Fix: Check if desc is provided and look up task by ID (like accept action does on lines 5476-5482), fall back to pending[0] if no ID given. Also update help text at line 5892.
accept: Run ralph task done t-xxxx with specific task ID and verify it marks that exact task, not the first pending one

name: Write async callback environment documentation
notes:
Create a brief doc explaining how async callbacks capture their environment:
1. Lambda captures definition environment at creation time (fun.env = env in valk_lval_lambda)
2. valk_evacuate_to_heap preserves lambda and its environment on GC heap for async callbacks
3. Function application uses func->fun.env as parent for call environment
4. Environment chain: call_env -> lambda closure env -> parent envs -> prelude -> global

Create docs/ASYNC_CLOSURES.md with this explanation.
accept: docs/ASYNC_CLOSURES.md exists and explains the 4 points above

name: Trace stream/open and nghttp2 data provider setup
notes: Part 1 of stream/closed debugging. Focus ONLY on tracing the setup path: (1) Add fprintf to stream/open builtin showing entry, (2) Add fprintf to nghttp2_submit_response2 call showing return value, (3) Add fprintf to data provider setup. Run a minimal test that just calls stream/open from an SSE handler. Document whether setup completes successfully. Remove debug prints after documenting.
accept: Document whether nghttp2 data provider is set up correctly when stream/open is called

name: Trace nghttp2 data read callback invocation
notes: Part 2 of stream/closed debugging. Focus ONLY on why __stream_data_read_callback is not called. (1) Add fprintf to __stream_data_read_callback entry, (2) Add fprintf to valk_http2_flush_pending showing if it is called after stream/open, (3) Check if nghttp2_session_mem_send2 is being called. This will reveal if the issue is nghttp2 not requesting data or our flush not triggering.
accept: Document why __stream_data_read_callback is never called

name: Fix stream/closed future completion based on debug findings
notes: Part 3: After tracing (subtasks 1-2) reveals root cause, implement the fix. Expected: either nghttp2 data provider not set up correctly, or flush not happening, or closed_handle not being completed in __stream_body_finish_close. Clean up all debug prints added in tracing tasks.

name: Add positive test for stream/closed future
notes: After stream/closed is fixed (t-t9zg), add a positive test to test/test_sse_builtins.valk that verifies stream/closed returns a future completing with :closed. Pattern to follow: open SSE stream in handler, get closed future, schedule stream close, verify future completes via aio/then. Keep test simple - 200ms timeout max.

name: Fix test_sse_concurrency_short.valk collect-as-you-go pattern
notes: The refactored test collects handles for 10 seconds then waits on all - but many connections time out by then. Fix: Use immediate aio/then on each handle to collect results into a shared list (via closure) instead of collecting handles. Pattern: each create-sse-connection should immediately chain (aio/then handle (fn {r} {append result to list})) and return nil. At end, just return the collected results. This matches original behavior: process results as they complete.
accept: build/valk test/test_sse_concurrency_short.valk passes within 60s, prints PASS
